Mechanistic insights into Schiff base incorporated double metal cyanide catalyst for the synthesis of colorless polyether polyols Akash Verma a b Bhawna Sharma a b Swati Saini a b Tolulope Oluokun a c Vishwas Saini a Deepak Khurana a b Tuhin Suvra Khan a b Sudip K. Ganguly a b Nagabhatla Viswanadham a b ⁎ Umesh Kumar a b ⁎ a CSIR - Indian Institute of Petroleum, Haridwar Road, Mohkampur, Dehradun 248005, India CSIR - Indian Institute of Petroleum Haridwar Road Mohkampur Dehradun 248005 India aPolymeric Materials Area, Chemical and Material Sciences Division, CSIR - Indian Institute of Petroleum, Haridwar Road, Mohkampur, Dehradun 248005, India b Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad 201002, India Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR) Ghaziabad 201002 India bAcademy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad 201002, India c Department of Chemistry, University of Ibadan, Ibadan 200005, Nigeria Department of Chemistry University of Ibadan Ibadan 200005 Nigeria cDepartment of Chemistry, University of Ibadan, Ibadan - 200005, Nigeria ⁎ Corresponding authors at: CSIR - Indian Institute of Petroleum, Haridwar Road, Mohkampur, Dehradun 248005, India. CSIR - Indian Institute of Petroleum Haridwar Road, Mohkampur Dehradun 248005 India The organic complexing agents (CAs) with multidentate sites help to enhance the active sites (Zn) of double metal cyanide (DMC) catalysts and also control the metal leaching from the DMC catalysts. Schiff base ligands (SBLs) are versatile and impart the coordination ability to bind with transition metals to form metal complexes. In this study, various SBLs are synthesized, and their use as CAs in DMC catalysts is thoroughly investigated. The metal complex formation is confirmed by structurally sensitive techniques, including SEM, PXRD, FT-IR, TGA, UV–Vis, AAS, CHNS, DLS, 1H-13C, XPS, and 13C-CP MAS spectroscopy. The 13C-CP MAS spectroscopy revealed strong coordination from N and O to the Zn sites of the DMC catalysts. XPS survey confirmed the presence of three types of cyanide (CN) carbons (axial, coordinated, and uncoordinated), four types of nitrogen (three from CN and one from azomethine), and Zn in +2 oxidation state. The ring-opening polymerization (ROP) was carried out using the prepared DMC catalysts to produce high-quality colorless polyether polyols (PPG). At an optimized reaction condition of catalyst amount = 250 ppm, time = 50 min, pressure = 5 bar, temperature = 105 °C, PO : PEG-600 = 4400 : 1, a maximum PPG yield (>95 %) is obtained with turnover frequency (TOF) of 11,292 h−1 (mol-PO per mol-Zn per hour). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were also performed to understand the nature of the active site and mechanistic insight into the polymerization reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Double metal cyanide catalyst Polyether polyols Ring-opening polymerization Schiff base Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Double metal cyanide (DMC) complexes, having a general formula M1[M2(CN)6].CA.nH2O, are generally prepared with a reaction of one metal halide salt (M1) and one metal cyanide salt (M2) in the presence of one complexing agent (CA) or co-CA. The DMC catalyst was first used for the ring-opening polymerization (ROP) of epoxides in the 1960s [1] and then explored for esterification, transesterification [2–4], hydroamination [5], prins condensation, CO2 fixation [6–8], and oxidation reaction [9–11]. Recently, Baerdemaeker et al. reported a liquid-assisted grinding method for silica-supported DMC catalyst to improve the catalytic activity for hydroamination of phenylacetylene with 4-isopropyl aniline and ROP of 1,2-epoxy hexane [5]. Numerous combinations of metal halide and metal cyanide salts are used to prepare DMC catalysts [12], but till date, Zn and Co have shown the best performance for the ROP of epoxides [5,13]. An organic CA plays a decisive role in enhancing the activity of the DMC catalyst by making the complex stable for ROP. The different CAs, comprising alcohols, amines, esters, and ethers, e.g., tert‑butyl alcohol (TBA) [2,13,14], 1,2-dimethoxyethane, 1-methyl-2-propanol, 1,2-propanediol, hexamethylenetetramine, 2‑methoxy ethanol, diglycolmethylether, 18-crown-6 ether, lactate esters and many more have been used for enhancing the activity of the DMC catalyst [12,15–17]. Kim's group recently reported the use of α-, ß-, and γ-diketones and ß-ketoesters (dicarbonyl compounds) as a CA for the synthesis of DMC catalysts [17]. Non toxic lactate esters were also explored by the same group for their use as CA with the DMC catalyst for producing polyols with high purity [15]. Very recently, the synthesis of heterogeneous DMC catalysts using EDTA as a CA for the controlled synthesis of PPG was reported in the author's previous work [18]. To date, TBA has received the most attention as CA for producing highly active DMC with a prolonged induction duration [19,20]. However, using TBA-based DMC catalysts is accountable for increased high molecular weight impurities in PPG products, prohibiting high-quality polyurethanes (PU) production [12]. PPG, also known as poly(oxypropylene oxide) (PPO), are majorly produced by the ROP of PO. The flexible PPG, having a glass transition temperature of −70 °C, are a class of non-crystalline polymers due to its racemic PO monomer (unsymmetrical epoxide). PPG are not water-soluble at room-temperature due to the presence of the additional methyl group in its repeating unit, leading to high steric hindrance in the polymer backbone. However, lower molecular weight PPG are soluble in water at low temperatures with a critical temperature of 15 °C [21]. PPG play an important role in the commercial production of PU foams due to their low glass transition temperature and amorphous nature [22]. PPG are also used as a precursor material for the production of lubricants, softeners, non-ionic surfactants, rheology modifiers, and antifoaming agents [23–25]. The high metal leaching from the DMC catalyst in the final PPG products have been considered as one of the prime factors in giving the color (e.g., yellow, white turbid) to the products, which ultimately affects in reducing the quality of PU [26]. However, we found a few literatures detailing about controlling the yellow color in the PPG by heating it to temperature range of 95 °C, which makes this process lengthy and cost-effective [27]. The colorless PPG are of current demand, which is rarely reported by the authors. Hence, there remains an enormous scope to design a catalyst that not only controls the metal leaching in the catalyst but also minimizes the need for extensive processing for metal removal from the prepared PPG. Schiff base, a condensation product of aldehydes/ketones and primary amines, is well known and used as an efficient catalyst for oxo transfer reactions [28,29] and other processes [30,31]. These ligands have a general formula, RCHNR’ (R and R’ are alkyl and aryl substituents), widely used in coordination chemistry [32]. These are tetradentate ligands, dianionic in nature, having a structure similar to porphyrins. The Schiff base ligands (SBLs) have been explored well in oxidation [33,34], epoxidation [35,36], oxidative coupling, Suzuki cross-coupling [37], oxidative amination, hydrogenation [38], and hydroxylation reaction [39]. But these ligands have rarely been used as CA for synthesizing DMC catalysts. Therefore, an enormous scope remains to explore the effect of SBLs as CAs for synthesizing novel DMC catalysts. In the present work, a series of SBL, including 2-(((3-hydroxypropyl)imino)methyl)phenol, 2,2′-((ethane-1,2-diylbis(azanylylidene))bis(methanylylidene))diphenol, 2-(((2-hydroxyethyl)imino)methyl)phenol, and 2-[(phenylimino)methyl]phenol were synthesized via a simple condensation method. The prepared SBLs were further used as CAs to synthesize Zn and Co-based DMC catalysts. The physicochemical properties and morphology of the prepared Schiff bases and DMC catalysts were determined by SEM, PXRD, FT-IR, TGA, UV–Vis, AAS, CHNS, DLS, 1H-13C NMR, XPS, and 13C-CP MAS NMR spectroscopy. The catalytic activities of the prepared DMC catalysts were tested for ROP of PO. The reaction conditions were optimized to control the properties of PPG. The DFT study was also performed to reveal the active sites and mechanistic insights into the ROP reactions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Methods and materials Zinc chloride (ZnCl2) was purchased from CDH Fine Chemicals and used without further purification. Potassium (III) hexacyanocobaltate (K3[CO(CN)6]), 3-amino-1-propanol, ethylenediamine, ethanolamine, aniline, and salicylaldehyde, were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. PO, glycerol (GL), 1,4-butane diol (1,4-BD), dipropylene glycol (DPG), neopentyl glycol (NPG), polyethylene glycol (PEG)−200, PEG-300, PEG-400, PEG-600, PEG-2000, CHCl3, and CDCl3 were obtained from TCI Chemicals Pvt. Ltd. and used without further purification. AR and HPLC grade THF (99.99 %) were purchased from Rankem Chemicals and Advent Chembio Pvt. Ltd., respectively, and dried before use. 2.2 Synthesis of SBLs The SBLs were synthesized by refluxing the equimolar amount of amine and aldehyde. The detailed synthesis method is given in Supporting Information (SI). The structures of SBLs are also given in Figure S5, SI. 2.3 Synthesis of DMC catalysts The DMC catalysts were synthesized by the coprecipitation method at room temperature, where the solution of the ZnCl2, metal cyanide, and complexing agents were mixed together and stirred. The PEG was used to keep the amorphicity in the DMC complex. The detailed synthesis method is given in the SI. The tentative DFT-optimized structures of DMC catalysts are given in Fig. 1 . 2.4 Synthesis of PPG To regulate the yield, OH, and I2 values of PPG, the ROP was performed in a Teflon-lined autoclave reactor (50 mL) having special provisions for gas in/out, gas purging, stirring, high pressure liquid injection, and collection. The DMC catalyst of the present work was used without further preactivation, unlike common DMC catalysts. DMC-1 catalyst (0.03 g) containing Teflon reactor was charged with PO (32 g) and PEG-2000 (1 g). The reactor was purged with N2 for 5 min at 20 mL min−1 flow rate to establish an inert environment and remove the dissolved gases from the reaction mixture, followed by pressurization with N2 to 5 bar. The mixture was stirred at 700 rpm and heated to 105 °C. After 30 min, a continuous increase in the pressure was observed till 40 bar. A sudden pressure drop (≈5 bar) was noticed over different time intervals, revealing the active form of DMC catalyst after the interaction of glycol followed by PO interaction and demonstrating the progressive formation of PPG. The unreacted PO was extracted by sending the gas portion of the Teflon reactor through the facility of a liquid nitrogen-cooled gas trap tube. Finally, the obtained product was vacuum-dried at 70 °C for 24 h, and the PPG was designated as PPG-1. The other catalysts, including DMC-2, DMC-3, and DMC-4 catalysts, were also scrutinized for ROP of PO by following the polymerization procedure mentioned above. The physicochemical properties such as yield, Mw, Mn, OH, PDI, and I2 values of PPG-1 to PPG-4 are enlisted in Table 4. 2.5 Characterization The characterization techniques and methods, including SEM, PXRD, FT-IR, TGA, UV–Vis, AAS, CHNS, DLS, GPC, OH value, I2 value, 1H-13C NMR, XPS, and 13C-CP MAS NMR spectroscopy were used for the detailed characterization of prepared SBLs, DMC catalysts, and PPG and are given in SI. 2.6 Molecular calculations Non-periodic, all electron, numerical basis set-based DMol3 DFT method [40] implemented in Material Studio 8 (Biovia, San Diego, USA) was employed to study the reaction energetics of the ROP of PO over DMC-4 catalyst. All DFT calculations were performed using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) exchange-correlation functional proposed by Perdew and Wang (PW91) [41] and used along with the double numerical plus polarization (DND) basis set with polarized d- and p- functions for all non-hydrogen and hydrogen atoms, respectively. Convergence criteria for the DFT calculations were kept at 0.0001 eV, 0.05 eV/Å, and 0.005 Å with respect to energy, force, and atom displacement, respectively. All the DFT calculations were performed using a spin-polarized set-up. To obtain the activation barrier for the polymerization reaction, a transition state (TS) search was performed with a linear synchronous transit/quadratic synchronous transit (LST/QST) method [42] using 0.05 eV/Å as force convergence criteria. During LST, single-point calculations were carried out on linearly interpolated structures on the minimum energy path joining the reactant and product states. The transition state is one which has the maximum energy along the minimum energy path. The structure obtained was taken as an intermediate for QST optimization, resulting in a more refined structure closer to the TS geometry. The authors have already successfully used a similar DFT setup to study various reactions [43–50]. The activation energy, Ea, was calculated using the following equation: E a = E TS − E IS where ETS and EIS represent the transition and initial state energies, respectively. The reaction energies, Er, for the reactions were calculated using the following equation: E r = E FS − E IS where EIS and EFS are energies of the initial and final states, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of SBLs 3.1.1 1H and 13C NMR analysis of SBLs The 1H NMR spectra of CA-1, CA-2, CA-3, and CA-4 are shown in Figure S6 (a, c, e, g). In the 1H NMR spectrum of the CA-1 (Figure S6-a), the peak that appeared as a quintet at δ 1.80 ppm is attributed to methylene (-CH2) proton (labeled as 2). The two triplets centered at δ 3.52 and δ 3.65 ppm are due to -CH2 protons labeled as 3 and 1 in the structure of CA-1. The multiplet observed in the region δ 6.86–7.42 ppm (labeled as 5, 6, 7, 8) is due to the aromatic protons of salicylaldehyde moiety [51]. The sharp peak that appeared at δ 8.53 ppm corresponds to azomethine proton (-CHN) labeled as 4 in the structure, which confirmed the successful condensation of salicylaldehyde and 3-amino propanol [52,53]. A similar peak pattern was observed for CA-2, CA-3, and CA-4 (Figure S6-c, e, g), and each proton's characteristic peaks are shown in Table 1 . The 13C NMR spectra of CA-1, CA-2, CA-3, and CA-4 are shown in Figure S6 (b, d, f, h). In the 13C NMR spectrum of CA-1 (Figure S6-b), the peak appeared at δ 34.04 ppm is due to -CH2 carbon situated between two carbon atoms of the 3-aminopropanol and labeled as 2. The peaks observed at δ 55.53 and 58.63 ppm are due to -CH2 carbon (labeled as 3 and 1, respectively) next to -N and -O atoms, respectively. The peak corresponding to azomethine carbon (CHN) formed due to the condensation between salicylaldehyde, and 3-aminopropanol appeared at δ 161.44 ppm (labeled as 4). Also, the phenolic carbon atom (labeled as 5) appeared at δ 166.25 ppm. The multiplet peaks in the region δ 116.99–132.62 ppm are due to aromatic carbon atoms of salicylaldehyde moiety (labeled as 6, 7, 8, 9, 10) [52,54]. A similar peak pattern was observed for CA-2, CA-3, and CA-4 (Figure S6-d, f, h), and each carbon atom's characteristic peaks are shown in Table 1. 3.2 Physicochemical properties of DMC catalysts 3.2.1 PXRD study The PXRD patterns of the synthesized DMC catalysts could be indexed to cubic lattices, as shown in Fig. 2 . The prepared DMCNC catalyst showed a cubic lattice structure (Fm-3 m) [55] showing its diffractions at 17.2°, 24.4°, 35°, and 39.4° corresponding to the planes (200), (220), (400), and (420) respectively [Figure S3 (a)]. Similar peaks were observed for DMC-1 to DMC-3 catalysts with different crystallite sizes [Fig. 2 (a–c)]. Especially for the DMC-3 catalyst, the 17.2° (200) peak was broadened drastically, and 24.4° (220) peak was slightly shifted to the lower side (24°) with the disappearance of 35° (400) and 39.4° (420). The emergence of the peaks at 14.5 ° and 19.2°, along with peaks at 17.2° and 24° revealed that DMC-3 catalyst exhibits a mixture of monoclinic and rhombohedral phases and most active for the ROP. But for the DMC-2 and DMC-4 catalysts, the intensity of diffraction at 17.2° (200) was significantly high. The peaks at 35° (400) and 39.4° (420) remained intense for DMC-2 but completely diminished for DMC-3 and DMC-4 catalyst. Also, the 24.4° (220) peak remained at the same position for DMC-2 but shifted to the lower side (24°) for DMC-3 and higher side (24.7°) for DMC-4 catalysts, respectively, after the complexation of synthesized SBLs [Fig. 2 (c, d)]. The details are mentioned in Table 2 . Since the activity is highly dependent on the crystalline nature of the catalyst [15], these results indicate that the coordination of SBLs reduces the crystalline nature of the catalyst and conclusively depicts the semicrystalline structure for DMC-1 and DMC-4, highly crystalline for DMC-2, and partially amorphous character for the DMC-3 catalyst. The calculated crystallize sizes for DMC-1, DMC-2, DMC-3, and DMC-4 catalysts are 53.3 Å, 72.8 Å, 68.2 Å, and 78.1 Å, respectively, lower as compared to the DMCNC catalyst (98.2 Å). 3.2.2 SEM study To understand the shape and morphology of the prepared DMC catalysts with different CA, scanning electron micrographs (SEM) images of the produced DMC catalysts were collected. The SEM images of the synthesized DMC catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . The DMCNC catalyst revealed the particles with irregular morphology, as shown in Figure S3(b). While DMC-1, DMC-2, DMC-3, and DMC-4 catalysts showed irregular cylindrical/rod type, spherical, needle type, and agglomerated irregular structure, respectively, Fig. 3 (a–d). These results indicated that the coordination of CA to the DMC catalysts would make the DMC solids amorphous in nature with different morphologies by inhibiting the formation of crystalline framework [56]. Additionally, the elemental composition of all the DMC catalysts was disclosed by the energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) plot, and analyzed semi-quantitatively (Figure S1). The EDX analysis disclosed that the amount of carbon (C), oxygen (O), and nitrogen (N) increased in the range of 44.0–56.9 %, 8.30–18.67 %, 22.49–31.0 % for all DMC catalysts, a much higher in comparison to the DMCNC catalyst as shown in SI (Table S1). These results also support the presence of coordinated SBLs in DMC catalysts in good accordance with the FT-IR results. According to the literature [57], ligands play a role in the amorphization of structure, which increases the surface of the material. Hence, our study confirmed that additional SBLs were introduced to all the catalysts as compared to the DMCNC catalyst. The elemental mapping of the DMC-3 catalyst also confirmed the major presence of Zn, Co, C, N, and O elements with low K and Cl content, as shown in Figure S2. 3.2.3 FT-IR study The FT-IR analysis confirms the presence of the functional groups and relevant stretching vibrations. Fig. 4 (A-D) depicts the comparative FT-IR spectra of the CA, [K3Co(CN)6], and DMC catalysts. Herein, the ʋ(CN) band in [K3Co(CN)6], observed at 2128 cm−1, was shifted to 2192 cm−1, 2191 cm−1, 2193 cm−1, 2192 cm−1 for DMC-1, DMC-2, DMC-3, and DMC-4 catalysts, respectively, confirming the σ-donor behavior by donation of electrons to Co and electron donor behavior of the CN− by chelating with Zn in the complex. The electron donation leads to increasing the ʋ(CN) as the electrons are removed from 5 s orbital. On the other hand, π-back bonding decreases the ʋ(CN) due to the transfer of electrons to the antibonding 2pπ* orbital [58]. Also, the azomethine group (-CHN) present in CA-1 to CA-4 observed at 1630, 1637, 1631, and 1616 cm−1 was shifted to 1648, 1642, 1658, and 1639 cm−1 in DMC-1 to DMC-4 catalysts, respectively. These shifts to higher wavenumbers confirmed the chelation and strong coordination via N of the azomethine group (-CHN) to the Zn sites of the DMC catalysts [59]. The multiple peaks ranging between 461 and 609 cm−1 in all the DMC catalysts are attributed to the metal-oxygen (Zn-O) bond [60,61]. Also, the peaks corresponding to the Zn-O and Zn-N bonds are also visible as a broad peak between 420 and 502 cm−1, confirming the possible coordination of SBLs from both O and N to the Zn sites of the catalysts [59,62]. Moreover, the peaks in the range of 3341–3501 cm−1 correspond to the aromatics CH bands in CA-1 to CA-4 and OH bands in DMC-1 to DMC-4 catalysts, respectively. For comparison, the FT-IR spectrum of DMCNC is also examined [Figure S3(c), SI], which revealed the sharp peak at 1609 cm−1 and broad peak at 3404 cm−1, ascribing the bending and stretching mode of the adsorbed water molecules, respectively. Also, the band corresponding to the stretching vibration of Zn-OH is also visible at 3658 cm−1, confirming that the Zn sites were occupied by more water molecules in the DMC catalyst when prepared without any CA [56] as compared to the DMC catalyst prepared with CA. 3.2.4 UV/Vis spectroscopic studies Electronic spectra of the synthesized SBLs and DMC catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 (a-b). All CA-1 to CA-4 complexes exhibit one broad and one sharp band at 315 and 259 nm corresponding to n → π* and π → π* transitions, respectively [63]. The band at 315 nm was shifted to higher wavelengths at 377, 379, 373, and 411 nm for DMC-1, DMC-2, DMC-3, and DMC-4 catalysts, respectively, after the complexation, possibly due to the merging of the ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) band with n → π* intra ligand (IL) band. Also, the band at 259 nm was shifted to 270, 270, 262, and 262 nm for DMC-1, DMC-2, DMC-3, and DMC-4 catalysts, respectively. In K3[Co(CN)6], two bands were observed at 262 and 313 nm attributing to the LMCT [64] as shown in Figure S3(d). The band at 313 nm has been shifted to 309 nm for DMC-1 and DMC-4 catalysts. However, this 309 nm band could not be located for DMC-2 and DMC-3 catalysts as it may have merged with broader 379 and 373 nm bands. These shifts are due to the bridging of the cyano group and the donation of antibonding electrons from CN− to Zn2+ and Co2+ ions. 3.2.5 Thermogravimetric study In order to manufacture high-quality PPG, the activation temperature is a crucial consideration in determining the weight losses of different fragments of the DMC catalyst. Herein, the mass loss stages of the DMC-1 to DMC-4 catalysts are shown in Figure S4(a–d). The DMC-1 catalyst showed the first weight loss of 3.2 wt% below 135 °C due to the water molecules released from the catalyst. The second weight loss of 17.8 % was detected in the temperature range of 150–400 °C as a result of the loss of coordinated CA-1. The simultaneous dissociation of cyano groups contained in the catalyst was observed in the range of 535 to 740 °C with a mass loss of 22.8 %. But the DMC-2 catalyst has a large amount of water molecules, clearly observed as a major loss of 23.4 % up to 150 °C. A similar weight loss of 29.1 % in the 195 to 600 °C range was observed due to the combined loss of coordinated CA-2 ligand and cyano groups present in the catalyst. This also confirms that more water molecules are coordinated with the DMC-2 catalyst as compared to the DMC-1 catalyst. The DMC-3 catalyst showed almost similar mass loss pattern to the DMC-1 catalyst [Figure S4(c)]. The DMC-4 catalyst showed sharp multiple decays due to bound water molecules, coordinated CA-4 and cyano groups present in the DMC catalyst [Fig. 3(d)]. Conclusively, the DMC-3 catalyst has low water molecules (3.3 % wt) bound to the catalyst as compared to the DMC-2 (23.4 wt%), DMC-3 (3.5 wt%), and DMC-4 (7.7 wt%) catalysts. This study confirmed the strong replacement of water molecules by CA-3 in the DMC-3 catalyst, which is also a prime cognition for the high catalytic efficacy of DMC-3 towards ROP. A similar type of study has also been reported by Kim et al., wherein they have shown the water decays of 0.8–4.5 wt% in the DMC catalyst containing CA much lower than DMCNC (12 wt%) [65]. 3.2.6 Particle size study Dynamic light scattering (DLS) is a commonly used technique for measuring the particle size of nanoparticles and colloids. Herein, the average particle size diameter of 1362.4 nm was observed for the DMCNC catalyst. While adding the CA into the DMC catalysts (DMC-1, DMC-2, and DMC-3), increased diameter up to 4110.6, 7386.7, and 3448.4 nm, respectively. But DMC-4 catalyst showed a decreased diameter of 515.1 nm. The obtained results revealed that the presence/binding of CA led to increasing the particle size of the DMC-1, DMC-2, and DMC-3 catalysts. It also confirmed that the strong coordination of CA to the Zn2+site of the DMC catalysts resulted in the DMC catalyst being long linear inorganic molecules, incongruent with PXRD, FT-IR, and UV–Vis study. Therefore, increased particle sizes of the DMC catalysts were observed. Conspicuously, the particle size study unveiled the importance of the particular size diameter (3448.4 nm ≈ DMC-3) of the catalyst for the high activity towards ROP of PO. The graph indicating the particle size diameter (nm) vs. intensity plot of all the DMC catalysts can be found in Figure S7. 3.2.7 XPS study 3.2.7.1 Zn XPS The coordination of CA to DMC catalyst, presence of elements, traces, and structure of the DMC catalyst was further confirmed by XPS analysis. The wide scan XPS spectra of the DMC catalysts revealed information regarding the presence of characteristic peaks of Zn 2p, Co 2p, C 1 s, O 1 s, and N 1 s signals, confirming the formation of DMC catalysts, as shown in Figure S9, SI. These spectra also ensured that the Zn, Co, C, O, and N are the main elements present within the surface regions of the catalysts. Furthermore, the binding energy of Zn in ZnCl2 (1023.7 eV) has been shifted to the lower values of 1022.21, 1022.12, 1022.28, and 1022.27 eV for DMC-1, DMC-2, DMC-3, and DMC-4 catalysts, respectively, confirming the coordination of CA to the Zn site of the catalysts. The replacement of Cl−by CN−ligand and coordination of CA to the Zn at the same time leads to the decrease in the electron-withdrawing power of the CN− ligand in the complex and hence lowers chemical shift values [66]. The detailed insights into the coordination of CA to the Zn were confirmed by expanded XPS spectra of Zn. Herein, the DMCNC catalyst (prepared without any CA) showed two singlet peaks corresponding to the binding energies of Zn 2p1/2 and Zn 2p3/2 spin orbitals at 1045.4 and 1022.3 eV. While, all DMC catalysts prepared with CA also showed two singlet peaks, corresponding to the binding energies of Zn 2p1/2 and Zn 2p3/2 spin orbitals, at 1045.3 and 1022.2 eV, respectively, a little lower as compared to the DMCNC catalyst, as depicted in Figure S10. These results indicated the existence of one coordination mode through CAs to the Zn sites of the DMC catalysts, in good agreement with the results obtained from FT-IR. The overall peak analysis is shown in Table S2, SI. 3.2.7.2 C and N XPS The peaks and binding energies corresponding to the C atoms of the DMCNC and DMC-3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 6(a-b) . In the DMCNC catalyst, two C 1 s peaks are visible at 285.7 and 285.1 eV, corresponding to the C of axial at cobalt and coordinated CN− with Zn as per the structure mentioned in Figure S8 (labeled as CN-1 and CN-2). In the DMC-3 catalyst, the peak appeared at 283.8 eV referred to the carbon atoms (C=C) of the aromatic ring and marked as C3-C4, C5-C6, C2-C8 [Fig. 7 (c)]. Another peak at a higher binding energy of 284.4 eV referred to the alkyl carbon (CC) atom marked as C1-C1’, C2-C7, C2-C3, C4-C5, C6-C8 [Fig. 7(c)]. Furthermore, the next C atom, relating to the azomethine (-CHN) group of the ligand, attached to nitrogen via conjugated double bond, in the DMC catalyst appeared at a higher binding energy side at 284.7 eV, which is in well resemblance with literature reports [67,68]. The peaks at further higher energies at 284.9, 285.2, and 285.6 eV correspond to the axial, uncoordinated equatorial, and coordinated equatorial CN− carbons of the DMC-3 catalyst, respectively. Similarly, a total of seven C peaks were observed at almost similar positions (with small shifts) for the remaining DMC-1, DMC-2, and DMC-4 catalysts, and related satellite peaks are shown in Figure S11(a-c) and Table 3 . The carbon peaks associated with the reference sp2 carbon atom are also visible at 284.8 eV in all DMC catalysts. The N XPS survey of DMCNC and DMC-3 catalysts is shown in Fig. 6(c-d). In the DMCNC catalyst, two N 1 s peaks are visible at 398.1 and 397.8 eV, corresponding to the axial and coordinated N of the CN− ligand, respectively. While the DMC-3 catalyst was deconvoluted to a total of four peaks, one of which, corresponding to the axial CN− remained at the same position (398.1 eV) as found in DMCNC catalyst. Another peak corresponding to the Zn coordinated CN− was shifted to a higher binding energy at 397.9 eV, a 0.1 eV shift. Additionally, two more N 1 s peaks were also observed, one of which refers to the uncoordinated CN− (397.6 eV) and another to the azomethine (-CHN) nitrogen (399.4 eV) due to the coordination of CA-3 to the Zn site of the DMC-3 catalyst. Other DMC catalysts showed axial CN− (398.1 eV) at the same position, confirming the no change in the axial CN− in the complex. However, few shifts in coordinated and uncoordinated CN− were also observed for the remaining DMC-1, DMC-2, and DMC-4 catalysts, as shown in Figure S11(d-f) and Table S3. These shifts in the binding energies of both C and N atoms could be due to the buildup of negative charge on the CN− ligand after the coordination of CA with Zn sites of the DMC catalyst. Consequently, the active metal centere (Zn2+) is in a position to donate the excess of electrons to the CN− ligand via π-back bonding, resulting a decreased binding energies of C and N of CN− ligand [69]. The presence of -CHN group in all the DMC catalysts prepared in the presence of the CAs confirmed the successful coordination of CAs to the DMC catalysts. This is congruent with the results obtained from PXRD, FT-IR, SEM, UV–Vis, and 13C-CP MAS NMR spectroscopy. 3.2.8 Solid state13 C-CP MAS NMR study The solid-state 13C-CP MAS NMR spectra of DMC-1 to DMC-4 catalysts are shown in Fig. 7. The 13C-CP MAS NMR spectrum of DMC-1 exhibited peaks at around δ 27.70 and 31.86 ppm, corresponding to the -CH2 carbon of 3-aminopropanol moiety [70]. The other two peaks of -CH2 carbon next to -N and -O atoms appeared at δ 63.41 and 70.88 ppm, respectively, and showed a downfield shift with respect to the same -CH2 carbon atoms present in the CA-1 (δ 55.53 and 58.63 ppm). This is possibly due to the complexation with the active metal center (Zn) via coordination through N and O atoms, thereby reducing the electron density on -CH2 carbon atoms resulting in increased chemical shift value. Also, the peaks that appeared in the region of δ 116.44–140.51 ppm are attributed to aromatic carbon atoms of the salicylaldehyde moiety. The peak appeared at δ 161.44 ppm due to azomethine (-CHN) carbon atom of CA-1 has also been shifted downfield to δ 173.96 ppm in the corresponding DMC-1 due to the complexation of N atom with the Zn sites of the DMC catalyst. In DMC-2 catalyst, a singlet was observed at δ 57.61 ppm, corresponding to the -CH2 carbon of the ethylene diamine moiety. The peaks in the region of δ 117.17–136.84 ppm marked the presence of aromatic carbon atoms present in salicylaldehyde. An intense peak at δ 169.90 ppm due to the azomethine and phenolic carbons was shifted downfield with respect to the azomethine and phenolic carbon atoms present in CA-2 at δ 161 and 167.42 ppm, respectively. This confirmed the complexation of CA-2 via the N and O of the -CHN and phenolic group, respectively, with the Zn sites of the catalyst. In DMC-3 catalyst, the broad singlet at δ 62.24 ppm corresponds to the -CH2 carbons of ethanol amine. Furthermore, the aromatic peaks were observed in the range of δ 119.63–137.47 ppm (multiple peaks). The carbon atom of the azomethine (-CHN) group in the catalyst appeared as multiple peaks centered at δ 173.76 ppm. The multiplicity observed in these peaks could be due to the merging of -CHN and phenolic carbon peaks of the catalyst. The peak at δ 173.76 ppm underwent downfield with respect to the -CHN peak of the CA-3 (δ 161.55 and 167.87 ppm), which construed the participation from N and O to the Zn sites of the DMC catalyst. In DMC-4 catalyst, the peaks that appeared in the region of δ 118.11–137.52 ppm were attributed to aromatic carbons of the salicylaldehyde and aniline groups. The peak at δ 159.42 ppm was referred to carbon atom of the aniline ring next to -CHN group, shifted downfield with respect CA-4 (δ 148.52 ppm). The other two peaks at δ 162.85 and 173.51 ppm were marked for -CHN and phenolic carbon atom, shifted downfield in comparison to CA-4 (δ 160.85 and 163.98 ppm). The maximum extent of the downfield shift was observed in the case of phenolic carbon, indicating the complexation of active metal center with the corresponding oxygen atom leading to the decreased electron density, thereby resulting in the chemical shift at a higher value. A few spinning sidebands (SSBs) were also observed in all solid-state 13C-CP MAS NMR spectra of the DMC catalysts and highlighted as marked as (*) in Figures [71,72]. The presence of SSBs confirms the existence of peaks corresponding to all SBLs, and the shift in the peaks confirms the coordination of SBLs to the Zn2+ in the DMC catalysts. 3.2.9 Elemental analysis The metals present in the DMC catalysts was calculated using the ASTM D1977–03 method. In DMCNC catalyst, the Zn/Co ratio was found to be 1.53. While adding the CAs in the catalysts, the Zn/Co increased to 2.53, 1.72, 2.10, and 2.0 in DMC-1, DMC-2, DMC-3, and DMC-4 catalysts, respectively. Clearly, Zn/Co ratio increased with the incorporation of CAs in the DMC catalysts. Similarly, C, H, and N, calculated by CHN analysis, ensured the increase in the C, H, and N percentages in the DMC-1 to DMC-4 catalysts as compared to the DMCNC catalyst, as shown in Table 1. These results confirmed the incorporation of CAs in the DMC-1 to DMC-4 catalysts. Surprisingly, a similar up and down trend in Zn/Co ratio was observed by XPS analysis for all DMC catalysts, as shown in Table S2. The most active catalyst (DMC-3) resulted in having a Zn/Co ratio of 2.1, 1.69, and 2.79 by AAS, EDX, and XPS analysis, respectively. 3.3 Catalytic activity on PPG properties To ensure that PPG was produced with the highest possible yield, the synthesized DMC catalysts were tested using catalyst amount = 750 ppm, reaction time = 24 h, pressure = 1 bar, temperature = 105 °C, M/I ratio = 1100 : 1, as shown in Table 4 . Meticulously, DMC-3 showed the highest activity towards ROP of PO, and therefore DMC-3 catalyst was selected as a representative catalyst to produce high-quality polyether polyols by optimizing the reaction conditions. 3.3.1 Optimization of reaction conditions The reaction conditions, including M/I ratio, pressure, temperature, catalyst amount, and time were varied using DMC-3 catalyst for the ROP of PO. At first, the effect of different M/I ratios was tested from 1100 to 11,000. The maximum yield of PPG (85.3 %) at a M/I ratio of 4400 with controlled PDI (1.84), OH (21.8 mg-KOH g−1), and I2 value (0.013 mequ. g−1) was obtained. Hence, further reactions were carried out using the 4400 M/I ratio. Further, the effect of the reaction pressure was carried out in the range of 1 to 15 bar at 105 °C and M/I of 4400 : 1. The maximum PPG yield of 91.1 % was observed at 5 bar pressure with a low PDI (1.63), OH (20.1 mg-KOH g−1) and I2 value (0.012 mequ. g−1). The most likely cause for the low activity at a pressure higher than 5 bar could be the formation of low molecular weight-based side products. Therefore, 5 bar pressure was optimized to run further reaction parameters. Moreover, the temperature was varied from room temperature (RT) to 150 °C, and the yield of PPG increased maximum yield of 91.1 % was obtained at 105 °C with controlled PDI (1.63). Further increase in temperature from 105 to 150 °C led to the explosive polymerization reaction and had low-quality PPG with high PDI, making their end-use PU application worse [73]. Hence, 105 °C was optimized for further reaction parameter investigation. Also, the catalyst amount plays an essential role in providing the optimum active sites to the initiator and obtaining high-quality PPG. The catalyst amount was varied from 750 to 175 ppm. It was observed that a stabilized and maximum yield (95.5 %) was observed by decreasing the catalyst amount up to 250 ppm with improved PDI (1.36) and lower OH (15.9 mg-KOH g−1), I2 value (0.009 mequ. g−1). But a further decrease in catalyst amount up to 175 ppm led to decreasing yield (35.6 %) due to the availability of less active sites of the DMC catalyst. The reaction time was also varied further from 1 to 24 h, and we were able to obtain the >95 % yield of PPG within a reaction time of 3 h, having similar properties. The reaction time below 3 h was not enough for the completion of the ROP reaction using DMC catalyst, leading to low activity towards ROP. The above-mentioned results clearly indicate the importance of having the optimum balance of reaction parameters in obtaining high-quality PPG, as shown in Table S3, SI. Also, the total amount of catalyst that remained in the final product was around 250 ppm, which cut down the need to remove the catalyst from the product. A low catalyst amount in the final product is also an advantageous factor for its further application in making good-quality PU. 3.3.2 Effect of initiators To regulate PPG yield, OH value, unsaturation number, PDI, and initiation time, the effects of initiators having different branch widths and chain lengths were tested using GL, 1,4-BD, NPG, PEG-200, PEG-300, PEG-400, and PEG-600. At the optimized reaction condition (catalyst amount = 250 ppm, temperature = 105 °C, pressure = 5 bar, reaction time = 3 h, and M/I ratio = 4400 : 1), The initiators, including GL, 1,4-BD, and NPG, showed less efficiency by producing only 25.7 % (PPG-20), 29.8 % (PPG-21), and 57.8 % (PPG-22), respectively. While PEG-200, PEG-300, and PEG-400 were able to produce 55 % (PPG-23), 62.8 % (PPG-24), and 76.3 % (PPG-25) yield of PPG, respectively. Importantly, PEG-600 further increased PPG yield to 91.8 % (PPG-26), with a low PDI of 1.35, OH value of 14.9 mg-KOH g-1, and I2 value of 0.008 mequ. g−1. This confirms that the carbon chain length has a direct impact on the relationship with the yield of PPG, whereas low molecular weight-based glycols have an inverse effect on the PPG yield. The 1H NMR spectra of PPG synthesized by using GL, 1,4-BD, NPG, PEG-200, PEG-300, PEG-400, PEG-600, and PEG-2000 are shown in Figures S14 and S15. In all PPG, the methyl (CH3) protons exhibit a chemical shift range of 0.7 to 1.2 ppm, showcasing notable peaks at 1.14 ppm. On the other hand, the protons of CHnO (where n ranges from 1 to 2) demonstrated a broader range of 3.0 to 4.0 ppm. Few extra peaks were observed in PPG-21 and PPG-22 wherein the peak at 1.61 ppm in PPG-21 (Initiator = 1,4 BD) corresponds to the presence of the -CH2 groups of the 1,4 BD and the peak at 0.88 ppm in PPG-22 (Initiator = NPG) revealed the presence of the -CH3 group of the NPG in the PPG backbone. However, no major changes were observed in PPG prepared with GL, PEG-200, PEG-300, PEG-400, PEG-600, and PEG-2000 since -CH2 and -CH groups of these initiators were overlapped by the characteristic -CH2 and -CH peaks of the PPG and perceived between 3 and 4 ppm. These spectra confirm the successful participation of different initiators in initiating the reaction, followed by the propagation and formation of different types of PPG. One more reaction was carried out using an external liquid injection facility (Injector). Herein, 0.010 g of DMC-3 catalyst, 1 g PEG-600, and 5 g PO was taken in an autoclave reactor and purged with N2 for 2–3 min at a flow rate of 20 mL min−1. Then after, it was kept at 105 °C and 5 bar pressure. A continuous increase in pressure (11 bar) was observed with the reaction progress, followed by a gradual drop (6 bar) within 5 min, indicating the activation of the catalyst. The remaining PO (27 g) was then injected into the reactor using a high-pressure injector. The same reaction conditions were followed for 45 min. The reactor was brought to room temperature slowly. Then after, the product was washed with CHCl3 twice and vacuum dried at 70 °C. The obtained PPG has a 98.3 % yield with better PDI (1.12), Mw (3587 g mol−1), OH value (10.8 mg-KOH g−1), and I2 value (0.007 mequ. g−1). This reaction cut down the need to run the reaction for longer hours and reduced the total reaction time from 3 h to 50 min, making the present process industrially viable as compared to the commercially available KOH catalyst. 3.3.3 Degree of polymerization (DP) and Mn of PPG The DP (number of repeating units of PO) and Mn of the PPG were calculated by using 1H NMR spectroscopy [74]. Two separate ROP reactions were carried out using 1,4-BD and NPG as initiators using optimized reaction conditions, as mentioned in 4.1.1. and labeled the synthesized products as PPG-28, and PPG-29, Fig. 8 . In 1H spectra, the comparison of the integral area of the end group and repeating chain (PO) allowed us to determine the DP in the PPG using the following formula; D P = ∫ C H 3 ( P O ) 3 X n ( E n d g r o u p ) ∫ E n d g r o u p In the above formula, n represents the number of characteristic protons of the relevant end group. Here, n is 6 and 4 for 1,4-BD, and NPG initiators, respectively. Also, the integral of protons correlated with the end group falls in the range of δ 0.73–0.90 and δ 1.50–1.66 ppm for 1,4-BD, and NPG initiators, respectively. Then after, the Mn of the PPG-28 and PPG-29 was calculated by multiplying the DP with the molecular weight of PO and adding with the Mw of the respective initiators having a formula; M n = D P X M P O + M I n i t i a t o r And the calculated Mn of the PPG-28 and PPG-29 are 974.5 g mol−1 and 550.1 g mol−1, respectively. 3.4 DFT results The intrinsic structure of the DMC catalyst has been a hurdle to unraveling the nature of active sites and the interactions of the reaction intermediates with the DMC catalyst [75]. Understanding the intrinsic properties of the DMC catalysts at the atomic level has become an important factor in order to design a better DMC-type catalyst having better kinetics and polymer property. Here, a detailed DFT study has been performed to understand the step-by-step process for the ROP of PO over the DMC-4 catalyst. DFT optimized geometry of the DMC-4 catalyst is shown in Figure S12. In the initiation step, the 1,4-BD molecule was adsorbed at the Zn center of the catalyst with Zn-O bond distance measured to be 2.5 Å, as shown in Fig. 9 (a). The adsorption-free energy of 1,4-BD at the DMC-4 catalyst was calculated to be endergonic by +6.6 kJ/mol [Fig. 10 (a)]. In the subsequent step, the OH bond of the adsorbed 1,4-BD was activated with an activation barrier of 39.9 kJ/mol [Fig. 10(a)→(a’)] and reaction-free energy +24.9 kJ/mol [Fig. 10(a)→(b)]. The geometry of the transition state (TS) for the 1,4-BD OH activation has been shown in Fig. 9(a’). During the 1,4-BD OH activation, the H of the –OH group was transferred to the O atom of the DMC-4 catalyst, where the OHCH2CH2CH2CH2O formed a bond with the Zn atom (Zn-O bond length 2.0) and the O atom of the DMC-4 catalyst was detached from Zn center forming –OH group, as shown in Fig. 9(b). In the next step, the PO molecule was adsorbed at the Zn active site at a distance Zn-O 5.2 Å (Fig. 9(c)). The adsorption-free energy of propylene oxide was calculated to be endergonic by 5.5 kJ/mol (Fig. 10(b)→(c)). The adsorbed PO then undergoes ring opening and coupling with the OHCH2CH2CH2CH2O moiety forming the adduct shown in Fig. 9(d). The ring opening and coupling reaction went through a TS, where a five-member TS was formed involving the Zn active site and the PO and OHCH2CH2CH2CH2O moiety, as shown in Fig. 9(c’). The adduct formed in this step has been shown in Fig. 9(d), where the coupling of PO and OHCH2CH2CH2CH2O to form OCH(CH3)CH2OCH2CH2CH2CH2OH where the O atom was bonded to the Zn active site forming Zn-O bond (Fig. 9(d)). The activation barrier for the ring opening and chain elongation step was calculated to be 59.2 kJ/mol (Fig. 10(c)→(c')), whereas the reaction free energy was estimated to be exergonic by −69.2 kJ/mol (Fig. 10(c)→(d)). Subsequently, a second PO molecule was adsorbed with endergonic adsorption free energy of 29.0 kJ/mol (Fig. 10(d)→(e)). Similar to the first PO ring opening and coupling reaction, the second PO molecule also underwent a similar reaction step as shown in Fig. 9(e)→(f), where the chain was further elongated, and adduct OCH(CH3)CH2OCH(CH3)CH2OCH2CH2CH2CH2OH was formed as shown in Fig. 9(f). The activation barrier for the second chain elongation step was calculated to be 34.2 kJ/mol (Fig. 10(e)→(e')). In contrast, the reaction free energy was calculated to be exergonic by −81.2 kJ/mol (Fig. 10(e)→(f)). In the polymerization termination step, a second 1,4-BD molecule was adsorbed at the DMC-4 catalyst Zn active center as shown in Fig. 9(g) with exergonic adsorption energy −50.0 kJ/mol (Fig. 10(f)→(g)). In the final reaction step (Fig. 9(g)→(h)), the H atom from the –OH group of 1,4-BD was transferred to the O atom of the polymeric adduct OCH(CH3)CH2OCH(CH3)CH2OCH2CH2CH2CH2OH to form the polymer chain HOCH(CH3)CH2OCH(CH3)CH2OCH2CH2CH2CH2OH. The activation barrier for the H transfer step was calculated to be 77.5 kJ/mol (Fig. 10(g)→(g')), whereas the reaction free energy was estimated to be exergonic by −9.0 kJ/mol (Fig. 10(g)→(h)). Finally, the product polymer HOCH(CH3)CH2OCH(CH3)CH2OCH2CH2CH2CH2OH desorb from the DMC-4 catalyst (Fig. 10(P)) with desorption free energy of 75.2 kJ/mol (Fig. 10(h)→(P)) and regenerating the active catalyst for further catalytic cycle. The overall activation barrier for the polymerization reaction was calculated to be +95.2 kJ/mol (Fig. 10(R)→(c’)), whereas the overall reaction is exergonic by −78.2 kJ/mol (Fig. 10(R)→(P)). The DMC-3 and DMC-4 catalysts have similar types of structures, with DMC-3 having an aliphatic -CH2CH2OH chain and DMC-4 having a -Ph group attached to the N atom (coordinated with Zn active site) of S.B-4, as shown in Fig. 3. Due to the presence of the -Ph ring, the lone pair of the N atom is in resonance, hence not easily available for coordination with the Zn center, decreasing the electron density at the active site. Whereas in the DMC-3 catalyst, the lone pair of N atom is easily available for coordination with Zn, hence having higher electron density at the active sites. Due to this difference in the electronic environment of the Zn2+sites, the DMC-3 catalyst shows higher ROP activity compared to the DMC-4 catalyst. Similar types of intermediates were formed during the ROP reaction over DMC-3 and DMC-4 catalysts, as also have been proposed in previous studies [75]. The ROP reaction energy profile of the DMC-3 catalyst may slightly vary from the DMC-4 catalyst and may have a lower activation barrier due to the higher electron density of the Zn2+active site. 3.5 Comparative study of DMC catalysts with precursors The synthesized DMC catalysts were compared with precursors, including ZnCl2, K3[Co(CN)6], DMCNC, and DMC-TBA catalysts for ROP of PO at a reaction condition of catalyst amount = 250 ppm, reaction temperature = 105 °C, pressure = 5 bar, time = 18 h, M/I ratio = 4400 : 1. Herein, ZnCl2, K3[Co(CN)6] showed negligible activity towards PPG with only <2 % yield. However, DMCNC and the most widely used DMC-TBA catalyst enhanced PPG yield up to 35.3 % and 37.3 %, comparatively higher than the precursors, as shown in Table 5 . Conspicuously, the DMC-3 catalyst was found to be highly active for ROP of PO and produced 98.3 % yield of PPG. However, DMC-DEM [CA= DEM (diethyl malonate)] and DMC-MAA [CA=MAA (methyl acetoacetate)] catalysts produced PPG with controlled PDI of 1.06 and 1.05 respectively, a slightly better than DMC-3 catalyst (PDI = 1.12). These PPG were produced at a relatively higher temperature (115 and 130 °C) using DMC-DEM and DMC-MAA catalysts, slightly higher than our work (105 °C) [56,65]. Moreover, both these catalysts (DMC-DEM and DMC-MAA) were prepared at 50 °C whereas we were able to prepare the DMC-3 catalyst at room temperature and the preparation of DMC-3 is environment benign and industrially viable catalyst as compared to the already reported DMC catalysts. Reaction conditions: Catalyst amount = 250 ppm, pressure = 5 bar, M/I ratio = 4400 : 1, TBA = tert-butyl alcohol, DEM = diethyl malonate, and MAA = methyl acetoacetate. Importantly, CA-3, prepared with salicylaldehyde and 3-amino propanol, exhibited the highest activity as a CA. Hence, DMC-3 was proven to be the highly active catalyst for ROP of PO and produced high-quality PPG with >98 % yield as compared to the DMC prepared without any CA (DMCNC). The catalytic activity is mostly dependent on the type and mode of coordination of CA's to the Zn2+ sites of the DMC catalysts [65]. Recently, Tran et al. reported the use of dicarbonyl compounds as CA's and elaborated in detail their mode of coordination to Zn2+ sites to the DMC catalyst [65,77]. Also, a new DMC type of catalyst [Zn2Co(CN)6]+, linked through the acetate group, has also been explained by Marquez et al. l [78]. They have focused on presenting a new layered structure to the family of DMC catalysts. In this work, we have focused on the use of SBLs as CAs and unveiled their coordination with Zn2+ sites of the DMC catalysts. Interestingly, two modes of coordination, through N and O of SBLs, were confirmed by FT-IR, XPS, and 13C-CP MAS NMR study. The prime target was to choose a bidentate ligand as a CA with a slight difference in the electronegativity, which could not only replace the maximum of water molecules from the DMC catalyst but also coordinate with Zn2+of the DMC catalyst. Our hypothesis is such that N coordinates strongly with Zn2+ sites and O remains labile, due to which the O-Zn bond can easily break and initiator molecules can easily interact with Zn2+to make it a vibrant, active center for further propagation in the ROP. Zn2+remains in the tetrahedral geometry, having coordination from both N and O atoms of the SBLs. Also, Co3+remains in the octahedral geometry having six CN− ligands attached to it. Two CN− ligands are in the axial position, two coordinated and two uncoordinated to the Zn2+, as evidenced strongly by the XPS study. These axial positions of the CN− ligand remained the same (≈285.0 eV) even after the incorporation of the SBLs into the Zn2+ sites. But few shifts were visible in the binding energies of uncoordinated and coordinated CN− ligands, possibly due to the electronegativity differences of CN− ligands after coordination of SBLs to the DMC catalyst, as explained in the XPS part. Also, the presence of the azomethine (-CHN) group ensured the successful coordination of SBLs to the DMC catalysts. The 13C-CP MAS NMR study also supported this hypothesis, wherein the azomethine (-CHN) carbon peak was shifted downfield due to the decrease in the electron density of N and O atoms of the SBLs after the coordination. However, broader C peaks (-CHN and -COH) were attained in DMC-1, and DMC-2 catalysts, multiplets for DMC-3, two separate peaks for DMC-4 catalysts, as compared to the pure SBLs as shown in Fig. 7 and Figure S6. Furthermore, Kim's group has only discussed metal leaching using organic solvents such as acetone, N,N-dimethylacetamide, N, N-dimethylformamide, N,N-dimethylformamide, dimethyl sulfoxide, nitromethane, and 1-methylpyrrolidin-2-one as CA and focused on the conversion of monomers in presence and absence of the DMC catalyst. In this work, we have focused more on the use of bidentate ligands as a CA to scrutinize the effect of synthesized DMC catalysts on the color of the final PPG products. The bidentate nature of the CAs in the DMC catalyst does not allow the metals to leach out in the final PPG products. Hence, colorless PPG products were obtained using the synthesized DMC catalysts, as shown in Figure S13. Overall, this work lends a new perspective towards further studies in DMC catalysis with novel CAs and unveils their structures which can also replace the industrially used single metal-based catalyst (KOH) and also DMC-TBA catalyst. 4 Conclusions A facile method for the synthesis of Zn and Co-based DMC catalysts is reported herein. Four different Schiff bases were prepared at an elevated temperature and used as organic CAs in the DMC catalyst to enhance the catalytic activity towards the ROP for the synthesis of colorless PPG. The ligand prepared with salicylaldehyde and ethanol amine was found to be the most effective CA (CA-3) for the DMC catalyst. Various structure-sensitive techniques, including SEM, PXRD, FT-IR, TGA, UV–Vis, AAS, CHNS, DLS, 1H-13C–, XPS, and 13C-CP MAS NMR spectroscopy, confirmed the molecular structure of Schiff bases and DMC catalysts. XPS analysis unraveled three types of CN carbons, four types of nitrogen, and Zn in +2 state. Subsequently, the strong coordination of N and O to the Zn sites of DMC catalysts was confirmed by 13C-CP MAS NMR spectroscopy. The DMC-3 catalyst, prepared with CA-3, showed the highest catalytic activity towards ROP of PO and produced 98.3 % yield with controlled PPG properties (Mw = 3587 g mol−1, PDI = 1.12, OH value = 10.8 mg-KOH g−1, and I2 value = 0.007 mequ. g−1) using PEG-600 as an initiator. The low molecular weight initiators, including 1,4-BD and NPG, also produced PPG successfully with Mw = 974.5 and 550.1 g mol−1, respectively, as confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. The free energy profile obtained for the ROP reaction provided insight into the active site of the DMC-4 catalyst, the transition state, and intermediates formed at the active site during the polymerization initiation, propagation, and termination steps. The activation barrier for the PO polymerization over the DMC-4 catalyst was calculated to be 95.2 kJ/mol. coredata.dc:description: The organic complexing agents (CAs) with multidentate sites help to enhance the active sites (Zn) of double metal cyanide (DMC) catalysts and also control the metal leaching from the DMC catalysts. Schiff base ligands (SBLs) are versatile and impart the coordination ability to bind with transition metals to form metal complexes. In this study, various SBLs are synthesized, and their use as CAs in DMC catalysts is thoroughly investigated. The metal complex formation is confirmed by structurally sensitive techniques, including SEM, PXRD, FT-IR, TGA, UV–Vis, AAS, CHNS, DLS, 1H-13C, XPS, and 13C-CP MAS spectroscopy. The 13C-CP MAS spectroscopy revealed strong coordination from N and O to the Zn sites of the DMC catalysts. XPS survey confirmed the presence of three types of cyanide (CN) carbons (axial, coordinated, and uncoordinated), four types of nitrogen (three from CN and one from azomethine), and Zn in +2 oxidation state. The ring-opening polymerization (ROP) was carried out using the prepared DMC catalysts to produce high-quality colorless polyether polyols (PPG). At an optimized reaction condition of catalyst amount = 250 ppm, time = 50 min, pressure = 5 bar, temperature = 105 °C, PO : PEG-600 = 4400 : 1, a maximum PPG yield (>95 %) is obtained with turnover frequency (TOF) of 11,292 h−1 (mol-PO per mol-Zn per hour). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were also performed to understand the nature of the active site and mechanistic insight into the polymerization reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic insights into Schiff base incorporated double metal cyanide catalyst for the synthesis of colorless polyether polyols
